definition:
A prime number $p$ is one of [*Euler’s lucky numbers*]{} if
$n^2 - n + p$ for each $0 < n < p$ is also a prime. Put another way, a
lucky number of Euler’s plus the $n$th oblong number produces a list of
primes $p$-long. There are only six of them: 2, 3, 5, 11, 17 and 41,
these are listed in A014556 of Sloane’s OEIS.

41 is perhaps the most famous of these. We can verify that 2 + 41 is 43,
a prime, that 47 is also prime, so are 53, 61, 71, 83, 97, and so on to
1601, giving a list of 41 primes. Predictably, 1681 is divisible by 41,
being its square. For $n > p$ the formula does not consistently give
only composites or only primes.
